entry.title: In S4 Hana Public Cloud there is only two control keys YBM1 & YBM2 , how to procure external service
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

In S4 Hana Public Cloud there are two control keys YBM1 & YBM2 there is nothing as PM03 as in on premise to procure external services.

In the above mentioned control keys if we add external work center with YBM2 control key its creating PR but that is not as item category D, which will not serve the actual purpose of external service procurement. 

Though  it could be achieved directly by adding Services in Service Overview, by linking external operation, but this is creating an additional extra line in PR which is non relevant to purchasing.

Could anyone help is there any possibility in S4 Public cloud to create a PR with item for SES, automatically from external operations as with control key PM03 (on premise), given there is no order type configuration in S4 Public cloud.

entry.title: Re: Marketplace App UX Design Guidelines for SAP Users
entry.content: Designing Marketplace apps for SAP requires balancing usability with SAP’s structured, data-heavy environment. Following SAP Fiori design principles provides a solid foundation for consistency, navigation, and layout, but it’s best to adapt them to suit specific workflows and simplify interactions. SAP users prioritize clarity, efficiency, and workflow continuity over aesthetics, so keeping interfaces intuitive, data well-organized, and actions contextual is key. Avoid cluttered dashboards, inconsistent terminology, or modal-heavy navigation, and focus on performance, accessibility, and seamless integration with SAP’s native experience. Ultimately, a well-designed SAP-integrated app should feel like a natural extension of the platform — boosting productivity without overwhelming the user.

entry.title: SAP业务数据云中的SAP Analytics Cloud分析云概况介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

 

SAP Analytics Cloud是什么？

SAP Analytics Cloud分析云是SAP业务数据云(Business Data Cloud, 即BDC)的核心分析组件，扮演着企业"数据大脑"的角色。它将BI、预测和Planning功能统一在一个云平台中，就像为企业配备了一位既能看懂历史、又能预测未来、还能制定计划的智能顾问。

 

 

SAP开发分析云的目的是什么？

解决企业面临的决策滞后挑战。传统企业的数据只能以原始数据的方式呈现，管理者难以获得全局视角进行快速决策，但借助BDC中的分析云功能就可以通过丰富的图表来更直观的了解企业的量化现状，了解过去，甚至是预测未来

 

 

Analytics Cloud可以用来干什么？

Analytics Cloud就像企业的"智能决策中心"，提供三大核心能力：

1. BI分析

自助式报表创建：业务用户可以像制作PPT一样拖拽创建专业的数据可视化界面

移动端访问：高管在出差途中也能通过手机查看关键业务指标

2. 预测分析

智能预测：基于历史销售数据预测下季度收入趋势

异常检测：自动识别费用支出中的异常模式

机器学习集成：无需数据科学背景即可应用AI算法

3. 企业计划

协作式预算编制：各部门可以同时在线编制和调整预算计划

情景模拟：快速模拟"如果销量增长20%"对整体业绩的影响

版本管理：自动跟踪预算修改历史和审批流程

 

 

Analytics Cloud和市面上常见分析工具有什么区别？

1. 三合一集成能力

传统方案需要分别购买BI工具、预测软件和规划系统，Analytics Cloud将三者统一，就像买了一台既能打电话、又能上网、还能拍照的智能手机，而不是分别买三个设备。

2. 平台优势

享受BTP技术平台企业级的安全、合规和治理能力，数据处理符合GDPR等法规要求，就像住在有专业物业管理的高端社区，安全和服务都有保障；同时原生和BDC内的其他数据集成，数据存储，数据建模工具集成，可以一站式的解决所有数据需求

3. 与SAP生态的完美结合

原生集成：与SAP系统通过配置即可连接，数据实时同步

统一体验：延续SAP Fiori设计风格，用户学习成本低

内容丰富：提供行业最佳实践模板和预构建分析内容

 

 

Analytics Cloud该怎么用呢？

使用Analytics Cloud就像为企业搭建"智能驾驶舱"，主要步骤包括：

1. 环境准备，账户权限配置，数据集成

2. 数据建模，KPI指标设计

3. 创建分析内容，低代码拖拉拽即可生成报表内容

4. 协作和分享，在企业内分享内容，获取反馈

 

 

 

关于本文内容有任何问题或见解，欢迎在评论区留下你的想法，如果时间紧迫，也可以直接联系到我 arthuryang1996@foxmail.com，感谢你的时间

entry.title: Standard Costing Input Parameters in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,
I am working on a Discovery phase project to assess whether SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can support our client's standard costing process.
I need to confirm if the following input parameters can be configured in the standard costing calculation (Scope Item: BEG - Standard Cost Calculation).
Required Input Parameters:

Design BOM - Bill of Materials created by design department
Production BOM - Bill of Materials with theoretical quantities
Process yield loss rate - Defect rate or scrap rate at manufacturing process level
Actual material consumption quantity - Including material yield/scrap considerations
Manufacturing version - Version control for BOM and routing
Work instructions / Activity types and rates - Labor and machine hour rates
Work center - Production resource master data
Material master - Item master data
Standard material price - Standard purchase price for purchased materials

Questions:

Can all of these parameters be maintained in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?
If any of these are not supported in the standard functionality, what are the recommended workarounds or alternative approaches?
Specifically, I'm concerned about process yield loss rate and material yield/scrap - where should these be configured?

Any guidance or reference to documentation would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: Extend in Flexible Item Category Determination
entry.content:
Business Overview

What's New in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1, you can create custom fields from customer material master and use them as business conditions in the flexible item category determination for sales quotations, sales orders, and sales orders without charge.

Prerequisite

1. APP: Custom Field, create custom field, choose business context: Sales: Customer Material.

Enabled all user interfaces and Business Scenarios

Publish the custom field, the system automatically creates a field with business context Sales: Sales Document Item.

2. Edit the custom field of Business Context Sales: Sales Document Item

Enable the data source I_SlsDocItmCatDetnItmCstmParam and C_SALESORDERMANAGE_SD

And relevant business scenario

3. Configuration Create BRFplus Objects for Sales Document Categories (SSCUI: 106584)

Choose the ITEM_CATEGORY_DETERMIATION Custom Adaptation, Copy the template, and then click Update BRFplus Objects

Click Simplified BRFplus Workbench, check the custom field exist.

Business Example: Specific customer materials are designated as free processes

Edit the decision table columns：

Set the custom field - customermaterial: Free; Item Category: CBXN

Note:

  • Field Sales Doc. Type; Item Cat. Group; Item Usage; ItemCat-HgLvltm is set mandatory. 
  • You need follow the table of SSCUI: Assign item categories .
  • You could set "is initial" as blank for the field.

4. APP: Manage Customer Materials，create the customer material

System Behavior

APP: Create Sales Order - VA01, input the customer, material, customer material and quantity, the item category will auto determinate as CBXN.

Many thanks

entry.title: How to Return Redundant Input Product Back to Original Logistics Area
entry.content:
In production, supplied input products may not been consumed completely, how to return these redundant input products back to original logistics area?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Return Redundant Input Product Back to Origina...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

There are two ways to achieve this:

  1. Open the supply task, under tab Line Items, confirm the quantity for the redundant input product that should be returned but with negative. For example, if 1 ea of input product ABC (ABC represents product ID) should be returned back to original logistics area, then maintain -1 ea as Actual Quantity for input product ABC, click Save. 
  2. Go to work center Internal Logistics, open common task New Removal, find corresponding input product in corresponding production logistics area, create a new removal.

Henry

SAP Support

entry.title: Accessing On-Premises HTTP APIs with SAP Joule Studio and SAP Cloud Connector
entry.content:
SAP Joule Studio enables you to design and build intelligent AI agents and skills that automate and optimize your business processes. To ensure these agents can operate effectively, it is essential to allow them to read from and write data to third-party systems using APIs. In a typical SAP landscape, some of these systems may reside on-premises. To securely access such on-premises systems, the SAP Cloud Connector is the recommended approach. This blog post will guide you through the process of setting up and connecting a Joule skill or agent project in SAP Joule Studio to integrate securely through the Cloud Connector.

The scenario is as follows: We have SAP Joule Studio running on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), while the On-Premises systems exposes its endpoints. To establish a secure connection, we will configure the Cloud Connector, create a destination, set up a SAP Build Actions Project and use that Action in a Joule skill.

Let's dive into the steps required to set up this integration and leverage the power of SAP Joule Studio in conjunction with the SAP Cloud Connector.

Prerequisite


Before proceeding with the steps outlined in this guide, it is essential to have an instance of the SAP Cloud Connector installed. While it is possible to install the Cloud Connector on a server, for the purposes of this demonstration, we will be using a Windows machine. We recommend following the instructions provided in this blog (https://blogs.sap.com/2021/09/05/installation-and-configuration-of-sap-cloud-connector/) to install and configure the Cloud Connector until the Subaccount is connected.

Second requirement is a BTP subaccount with a SAP Build Process Automation (Joule Studio) instance. To this subaccount we will connect the Cloud Connector.

1. Cloud Connector Configuration


The first step is to create a configuration in the Cloud Connector that connects to our subaccount and exposes the HTTP resource. For the purpose of this demonstration, I ran a small Node.js server on my Windows machine that outputs “Hello World”.

To create the configuration, navigate to the admin interface of the Cloud Connector. In here you need to select your registered Subaccount where your SAP Build Process Automation instance resides. Then create a “Cloud to On-Premise” configuration.

 

In the provided screenshot, you will notice that I have exposed the internal host "localhost" with port 3333 using a virtual host named "virtualhost". This virtual host will be used for making requests from the BTP side. Currently, I have configured an unrestricted access policy, allowing access to all paths. However, in production scenarios, it is recommended to define access policies with more granular control.

Please note that it is crucial to ensure that you have exposed the necessary resources in your configuration. This ensures that the required endpoints are accessible and allows for successful communication between the cloud and on-premises environments.

In this example, the system type is a Non-SAP System using the HTTP protocol. To confirm that the connection works, you can use the “Check availability of internal host” button. This step is essential, as it verifies the accuracy of your configuration and ensures successful connectivity between the cloud and your on-premises environment.

Note: It’s important to understand the difference between the internal and virtual host. The internal host refers to the hostname accessible within your on-premises network — in this case, it’s the localhost on my laptop. Later, within SAP BTP, we’ll reference the virtual host instead.

On the BTP Cockpit end, we can check the connected Cloud Connectors in the respective menu tab. If you cannot see this tab, you may be missing some roles. In the image, you see my registered Cloud Connector and the backend system with its virtualhost available.

2. Create Destination


After successfully registering the Cloud Connector, the next step is to create a destination. A destination serves as a means for services to access an API by handling the authentication and networking aspects.

By configuring a destination, you can simplify the process of accessing APIs by abstracting the underlying technical details. The destination takes care of handling authentication, network communication, and other necessary configurations, allowing services to focus on consuming the API and performing business logic without worrying about the underlying implementation.

Creating a destination provides a convenient way to encapsulate the necessary information, such as the API endpoint URL, authentication credentials, and other relevant settings. This abstraction helps streamline the integration process and facilitates secure and reliable communication between your services and the targeted API.

 

When creating the destination, there are several important details to specify. These include the name of the destination, the URL you want to access, and the type of destination. In this case, we will specify the URL as the virtual host "http://virtualhost:3333". To utilize the Cloud Connector, we set the Proxy Type to On-Premise.

Optionally one can also maintain the Authentication detail - my service does not require these.

Once the destination configuration is complete, it is crucial to use the "Check Connection" button to verify that everything is configured correctly and the connection can be established successfully. This step ensures that the destination is functioning as expected and is ready to be utilized in your automation processes. 

Note: Did you know? The Destination Service’s “Check Connection” behaves slightly differently when the destination is configured with the proxy type “OnPremise.”

For public APIs on the internet, the connection check typically validates both the authentication credentials and the specific path — in other words, it performs a real GET request on that endpoint.

In contrast, for on-premise HTTP destinations, the check is much simpler. It only performs an HTTP “ping” on the host to verify that some response is received. Even if the target system returns a 5xx error, the check will still show as successful as long as the Cloud Connector tunnel is reachable and the HTTP server responds.

Be aware that this behavior can have downstream effects when troubleshooting connectivity issues.

 

 

In the ideal case you get the green checkmark! But there are some common errors we need to discuss:

 

 

The "Backend not available" error occurs when the connectivity service is unable to locate the host you are trying to access. This could be due to the host not being exposed in the Cloud Connector configuration or a potential misspelling in the URL. To resolve this issue, it is important to revisit the URL and ensure that you are using the correct virtual host specified in the Cloud Connector configuration. Verify that the URL is accurate and matches the virtual host configuration to establish the necessary connectivity.

 

The second common issue that may arise is the "Resource not accessible" error. This occurs when the connectivity service successfully locates the backend you intend to connect to, but the specific resource (such as the subpath "/hello") either does not exist or is not allowed to be accessed based on the rules defined in the configuration. To resolve this, ensure that you have included the correct path in the Cloud Connector's resource configuration.

For the usage in SAP Build - there is one additional step to make the Destination available to be used inside the Build tool. We need to register the Destination in the Control Tower of SAP Build:

We can do so by navigating to SAP Build Control Tower > Destinations and then choose Add to add the Destination to our environments.

3. Create Actions Project

Now, let's dive into SAP Build Process Automation and create an Actions project. In this case, since my API is not a standard one, I will create a custom API Specification. However, if you are working with a target system like S/4HANA, you can leverage the pre-defined API Specifications available in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Let's give the Project a name of our choice and choose the option to "Upload API Specification".

SAP Build Actions allow us to upload OpenAPI Specifications in JSON format.

 

{
  "openapi": "3.0.0",
  "info": {
    "description": "Demonstration Hello World",
    "title": "helloworld",
    "version": "1.0.0"
  },
  "servers": [
    {
      "url": "empty"
    }
  ],
  "paths": {
    "/hello": {
      "get": {
        "summary": "get hello",
        "description": "get a hello world message",
        "operationId": "get.hello",
        "responses": {
          "200": {
            "description": "Successful response",
            "content": {
              "application/json": {
                "schema": {
                  "type": "object",
                  "title": "Message Object",
                  "properties": {
                    "message": {
                      "type": "string"
                    }
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

The provided code snippet represents the API Specification, where I define the necessary details. In this case, the servers section is left empty as the URL will be retrieved from the destination configuration at a later stage. Additionally, I specify the available path as "/hello".

It's important to note that the path mentioned in the API specification will be preceded by the destination's URL. Therefore, in our scenario, the complete URL for the request will be "http://virtualhost:3333/hello".

Another crucial aspect for the functionality within the low-code environment is defining the expected response structure. In this case, the response payload will consist of a plain object with the key "message". To build and test specifications, you can utilize the website https://editor.swagger.io/. Be aware, that the response structure must match the specification; if, for example, fields are missing, you will be prompted with a schema error.

Once you have finalized the specification, save the file as a .json format and proceed to upload it to the Actions project.

Within the Actions Project, you will be prompted to add the desired actions, which you can proceed to do. Now, let's move on to testing:

Within the selected Action, navigate to the "Test" tab. Here, you have the option to select the destination that serves as the basis for the request. For this demonstration, I will choose the "sap-sample-api-via-cloud-connector" destination that I created earlier. Once the test is executed, you will find the response payload displayed at the bottom. In this particular case, the test is successful, and I receive the expected message from my On-Premises server.

If you encounter an error during the process, make sure to check the "View API" Section for any response body that might provide insights into the cause of the issue.

In the final step, we need to release and publish the Action to ensure its availability for consumption in an Project. To accomplish this, locate the buttons located at the top right-hand side of the Actions editor. Click on these buttons and ensure that the status indicates "released" and then "published."

4. Add Action to Joule Skill

Lets create a Project and include the Action in a Joule Skill. Do so by adding a step in the Skill with the + symbol.

First we need to add the Action Project in our dependencies:

We add a Action to the Skill, configure its Destination field by creating a new Destination Variable we give an arbitrary name.

We can see that the Action has the message variable in its output.

To prove that we can now also use the data from the API, I added an additional step to Send a Message with the API's result "message" variable in its content.

With the message editor - we can send a custom message to the user. In this case I keep it simple and just output the response from the message field of the API response.

 

After going through the standard deployment process in SAP Build Joule Studio - we can test our newly deployed skill directly in Joule.

And in this case we are successful and can retrieve the actual answer from the On-Premises HTTP System.

In the following posts we aim to provide further guidance on how to connect to a SAP On-Premises System - as this is the most common scenario for the extension of Joule. Take this blog post as the basis for understanding the concept and flow.

Hope you find this blog insightful, if you have any questions feel free to leave a comment.

entry.title: Re: Cost Price of item unexpectedly zero
entry.content:
Hi Johan,

 

Purchase Invoice functions in the same way as closing a Work order - it corrects the value of stock of that item. From what you attached you can see that it reduced the value of the remaining quantity (5 pcs) by the available value (3,85). I can only assume that the difference between posted value on the Goods Receipt and Invoice was equal or greater to 3,85, which caused the value of your remaining stock to be set to zero.

Inventory Audit Report is showing you quantites and values which were applied to a certain document. So you can see, the Purchase Invoice you mention has Quantity 0, and value 0,77. This means that remaining stock was valued at 0,77 for that transaction, and the negative in Trans. Value indicates that this amount was actually reduction of stock value at that point. Now, if you take a look at the journal entry of this Invoice, you will see what happened. In case the difference was greater than 3,85 value you had remaining, that should go to some offset account defined by your posting rules.

 

BR,

Matija

entry.title: SAP业务数据云中的Datasphere概况介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

Datasphere是什么？

SAP Datasphere是SAP业务数据云(Business Data Cloud,即BDC)的核心数据建模与数据集成组件，扮演着企业"数据中心"的角色。它将数据集成、数据建模、业务建模和数据治理功能统一在一个云平台中，负责连接、整合和建模来自SAP和非SAP系统的数据，确保数据在不同系统间安全高效地流动并保持业务语义。

 

 

SAP开发Datasphere的目的是什么？

解决现代企业面临的数据孤岛和混合IT环境挑战。如何让企业异构系统的数据无缝协作，同时保持SAP数据的业务语义，成为关键问题。

Datasphere与SAP BTP生态系统的其他功能协同工作：SAP HANA Cloud提供湖仓一体的数据存储能力，SAP Analytics Cloud实现数据消费与展现，与SAP Databricks相互调用模型/数据，并与S/4HANA等业务系统深度集成，形成完整的企业数据和分析解决方案。

 

 

Datasphere可以用来干什么？

Datasphere就像企业的"数据统一平台"，连接并保存各个业务系统的数据，以最典型的数据集成和建模场景举例：

1. 数据连接与集成

支持所有主流数据源连接，无论是SAP系统（S/4HANA、BW等）还是非SAP系统，都能无缝对接

内置预构建连接器，针对特定应用可以节约集成工作量

提供开箱即用的业务内容包，填写系统信息即可快速部署

2. 低代码数据建模和转换

支持图形化拖拽方式创建数据模型和转换流程，业务用户也能轻松操作

提供强大的SQL编辑器满足复杂建模需求

支持数据虚拟化、复制和转换等多种数据处理模式

3. 业务语义建模

保持SAP系统的业务语义和上下文，让数据更有意义

支持多维分析建模，内置数据预览功能

提供数据治理和目录功能，确保数据质量和可发现性

 

 

Datasphere和市面上常见的数据平台有什么区别？

1. 统一业务语义层的独特优势

这个平台结合BDC内各个组件，将数据集成、建模、治理和消费能力整合在一起。这就像拥有一个"数据管理的瑞士军刀"，而不需要购买多个独立的数据工具。

2. 基于BTP的平台优势

Datasphere享受BTP平台整体的安全、监控和治理能力。这就像住在一个配套完善的智能社区，所有基础设施都是现成的，无需自己搭建。

3. 与SAP生态的完美结合

深度集成：与SAP S/4HANA、SuccessFactors等SAP产品原生集成，保持业务语义

统一体验：共享SAP Fiori设计语言和操作习惯

预构建内容：提供丰富的SAP业务内容包和最佳实践模板

相比其他数据平台在获取到数据后需要完成的复杂业务语义重建工作，Datasphere为SAP客户提供了"即插即用"的数据管理能力，特别适合以SAP为核心的企业IT环境。

 

 

Datasphere该怎么用呢？

使用Datasphere就像为企业搭建"智能数据中枢"，主要步骤包括：

1. 获取，配置环境，分配权限

2. 建立数据表和对应的数据集成管道

  • 可以无缝对接SAP私有云系统，公有云系统
  • 还可以通过低代码开发对接各种非SAP数据
  • 甚至可以通过零拷贝的方式使用对象存储技术的数据源，无需真正导入数据，即可开始建模，消费

3. 数据建模和转换

  • 利用低代码工具创建数据模型和业务视图
  • 配置数据转换逻辑和业务规则

4. 部署和消费

  • 将数据模型部署到生产环境
  • 通过SAP Analytics Cloud或其他工具消费模型计算后的数据进行分析
  • 整个过程采用自助式操作，业务用户通过直观的界面就能完成专业的数据管理工作，大大降低了技术门槛，让每个业务专家都能成为数据建模者。

entry.title: Re: Manage multiple internal numbers and quantities per D...
entry.content:
In standard SAP outbound delivery processing, each delivery item typically corresponds to a single material number and quantity. However, if your business process requires managing multiple internal numbers or quantities under one delivery item—such as handling batches, packaging units, or sub-items—you can achieve this through several configuration and functional approaches.

First, you can use batch management to differentiate materials internally without creating multiple main items. Each batch has its own internal number and quantity but links back to the same delivery item. Similarly, handling units (HU management) let you group various internal numbers or partial quantities within one delivery item for warehouse or shipping purposes.

If you need to reflect internal numbers as separate identifiable lines, consider using delivery sub-items or item categories that allow item splitting. Item category determination can be customized in configuration (transaction VOV7) to automatically create sub-items during delivery creation.

Another approach is to leverage serial number management when tracking multiple serialized items under one delivery. Each serial number can represent an internal number tied to the same delivery item.

In short, depending on your requirement—batch, handling unit, or serial tracking—you can manage multiple internal references and quantities per delivery item through proper SAP configuration and master data setup.

Hello Klaus-Peter @kpsauer , SAP team,

Thank you very much for the great resume of the new Datasphere features - as always very helpful and nicely explained!

The new secondary Structures functionality was eagerly waited by us, however there seem to be still some restrictions on it which I would like to address also to you/your team and hopefully you would consider them for the next release.

1) New Structures not consumable via SAC Excel Add-in -> When we create Structure members in the Analytic model, they appear only if we consume the Analytic model in SAC story or via the Data Analyzer in SAC, but not in the SAC Excel Add-in, which is very important and limiting at the moment for our end users who want to use the SAC Excel Add-in functions. I noticed that if we open a BW Query (which also contains analogical Structure members) again via the SAC Excel Add-in, the Structure from the BW query is appearing. So, the issue seems to be for Analytic models consumption only - is this a bug or known/expected behavior? 

2) Structure members ordering not possible on AM level -> this is very inconvenient as currently could be done only on SAC level while if it was possible on AM level it would be much easier and make it reusable afterwards upon consumption in SAC.

3) Measures structure members ordering and grouping (like hierarchical display) not possible on AM level -> currently we cannot order, group and make like nested display (hierarchical with collapse/expand option) of the Measures as primary Structure as well, like it was possible in BW queries. This is very inconvenient for Measure-based models and very crucial, especially for Financial reporting where special ordering and grouping is important and setting this on AM level would make it reusable for later consumption in SAC. There is also currently Influence request from other colleagues (Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence) on which we've voted and commented, really hoping on sooner resolution.

We would be very thankful if you can consider all these topics and advise if there is workaround or possible current solution for them. Thank you very much in advance!

Best regards, 

Diana

Hi @Agustina_Palma,

By default, the Candidate Profile Extension is not displayed in the candidate profile. It becomes visible only after at least one field has been defined within the Candidate Profile Extension Object.

Navigation to create custom field in candidate profile extension:

Home page -> configure object definition -> select Object Definition in first dropdown and select candidate profile extension in second dropdown -> click on take action make correction and add custom fields.

To hide the Candidate Profile Extension from the candidate profile, remove all custom fields that have been defined within it.

Navigation to remove the custom field which defined in candidate profile extension: 

Home page -> configure object definition -> select Object Definition in first dropdown and select candidate profile extension in second dropdown -> click on take action make correction and remove the defined custom fields.

entry.title: Import bulk of custom fields in Data Migration modeler (LTMOM) using Upload Structure Field List
entry.content:
Challenge: When migrating complex master data like Business Partner - General Data (BP) to S/4HANA, you often receive requirements for over a hundred custom Z-fields sourced from a legacy system like CRM. Manually adding these fields one-by-one in the #LTMOM (Migration Object Modeler) is incredibly time-consuming and prone to errors.

Solution: Leverage the Upload Structure Field List option within LTMOM, as this feature allows you to bulk import field definitions using a simple text file, and it drastically reduce development time as well.

Summary of Step-by-Step Guide: Uploading Custom Z-Fields

Example with BP General data Z-Fields:
The following steps focuses on creating a new, user-defined migration object to handle the custom fields for the BP General Data (BUT000 table), using Function Module as the target.

How to create the Custom Migration Object
Execute transaction code LTMOM (Migration Object Modeler).

Select and Open the Project which was created in LTMC already.

In the menu bar, navigate to Project → Create Migration Object → User-Defined → Migrate Data Using Files/Staging Tables.


Enter the required Object ID and the description. Then choose the Function Module as the Target Structure option, then click Next.


Prepare the Source Structure File
Before creating the source structure, you must prepare the text file containing the field definitions.

  • File Format: Use a Text File with a Semicolon (;) delimiter. (Note: Standard comma-separated values (CSV) often fail with a pop-up error, even if the data is clean.)
  • Data Structure (Meta Format): The file needs to adhere to a specific structure for each Z-Field:
    Key FieldNameData TypeLengthDecimal PlacesAmount FieldLong Field LabelGroup TextCheck TableTooltipCustom Field

 






Create and Upload the Source Structure
In the LTMOM sidebar, double-click on Source Structure.

Right-click on the right sidebar and choose Append Structure to Lower Level. Enter the desired      name for your source structure (e.g., ZS_BP_CUSTOM).
Click the Upload Structure Field List option.

Browse and select your semicolon-delimited text file. The system will now generate all 100+ fields automatically.

Save changes and successfully created source structure using upload file.

Conclusion: Efficiency Through Correct Delimiter
As you can see the step-by-step guidance, by utilizing the Upload Structure Field List along with the semicolon-delimited text file, the development time can be significantly reduced. This approach streamlines the addition of high volume of custom fields in the existing Function Modules with maximum efficiency and minimal manual effort.

entry.title: Re: BEJ Inventory Valuation for Year-End Closing - on sto...
entry.content:
Hi there,

 
No, it is not possible to run different valuation practices for different storage locations within one company code/plant in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud .

Key Limitations

Material valuation occurs at the plant level only - In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, each plant represents a valuation area, meaning valuation is performed at the plant level rather than at storage location level . This is a fundamental design principle that cannot be changed.

Storage location valuation is not supported - Even in on-premise systems, SAP does not support material valuation at storage location level. The system only supports split valuation based on valuation type, not storage location .

Technical Background

The valuation area in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is fixed at the plant level . This means:

  • Price control and pricing are valid for one plant at a time
  • Material valuation data is created per plant
  • Different valuation practices can only be implemented across different plants, not within storage locations of the same plant

Alternative Solutions

1. Use Different Plants

If you need different valuation practices, consider setting up separate plants for different valuation requirements, as materials can be valuated differently in different plants .

2. Valuation Type Split

For materials requiring different valuations within the same plant, use split valuation based on valuation type rather than storage location .

3. Special Stock Management

For specific scenarios like consignment or special stock, the system provides alternative stock management approaches that don't rely on storage location-level valuation .

Price Difference Distribution

When price differences occur, the system automatically distributes them proportionally across all storage locations within the plant based on stock quantities, as shown in the automatic distribution functionality [4]. This ensures consistent valuation across all storage locations within the same plant.

The restriction to plant-level valuation is a core architectural decision in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud that cannot be customized or changed through configuration.

 

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better.

entry.title: Re: What I Wish I Knew
entry.content:
Hello Team,

As a customer embarking on the journey with SuccessFactors, there are a few critical points I wish I knew.

First and foremost, it is essential to stick to SAP standard as much as possible. Align your processes and configurations with the best practices recommended by SAP.  It is very tempting to customise the system to fit your previous ways of working, but it's important to let go of your old system(s) thinking.

Additionally, I encourage you to automate your processes as much as possible. A critical review of each process is necessary and to play devil's advocate and question why it can't be changed. 

When transitioning from SAP HCM payroll to Employee Central Payroll (ECP), it's important to understand the relationship between the two systems. Employee Central (EC) acts as the master, while ECP functions as the slave. This means that EC will be the primary source of data, and ECP will rely on it for payroll processing. 

By keeping these points in mind and approaching the implementation with an open mind and a willingness to adapt, you will be well on your way to a successful SuccessFactors experience.

That is what I wished somebody told me at the beginning.

Best regards,
Helette Slabber

entry.title: Introduction to Background Processing Framework
entry.content:
In this article we will look at bgPF and how you can use it in ABAP Cloud to move process to the background. Using an example will understand how the two variants that are offered for processes works.

Introduction

we come across multiple applications that help us buy, rent, or find information about something. Consider, for example, a train booking application with a screen for calculating the best and cheapest route to a destination. If you choose an offer, the application searches for activities you can do at the destination. Often, these applications redirect you to an activities screen where you still have to wait for the results. But what if you want to search for another destination instead of waiting?

That's exactly when the background processing framework (bgPF) comes into place. You can realize a workflow that searches for activities in the background while you're on your next journey: The bgPF offers the functionality to execute time-consuming methods asynchronously if you do not need the result immediately. Instead, you can continue processing and come back to the result later. Considering this process, changes in the current logical unit of work (LUW) (like triggering functionality in a different session than the current one) require compliance with the SAP LUW.

LUW [Logical unit work] and Transactional Phases

In business applications, a transaction describes a sequence of related and/or interdependent actions, such as retrieving or modifying data. The result of the transaction is a consistent state of data.

The time interval in which one consistent state of the database is transferred to another consistent state is called a logical unit of work (LUW). The LUW concept follows an all-or-nothing approach: it ends either with a single and final commit, which persists the changed data in the database, or with a rollback (for example, in the case of an error during the LUW), which undoes all changes and restores the consistent state before the changes.

Either all data changes are committed, or none at all. When a new consistent state is reached after a commit, or when an original state is restored, a new LUW can be opened.

There are two transactional phases in a transaction, which together form a logical unit:

  • modify
  • save

The two transactional phases can be realized as follows. The logical unit involves user interaction. For example, a user must make entries in input fields. These entries must be validated before they are saved. If, for example, there are incorrect entries or mandatory entries are missing, the user is prompted to update the entries. Only if the entries are valid, the final save can be triggered.

Variants

The framework currently offers two different variants of processes that are used for execution. If you are using the ABAP RESTful Programming Model, you should use the "Controlled" variant; for all other use cases, it is best to stick with "Uncontrolled".

Using the bgPF with transactional control [Controlled Variant]

The controlled SAP LUW concept is automatically and implicitly supported by RAP. That means the transactional phases are automatically and implicitly set when executing RAP BO logic implemented in ABAP behavior implementations in an SAP LUW in RAP. Calling RAP handler methods in the RAP interaction phase and the early save phase happens automatically in the modify transactional phase. When the late save phase is reached, the modify transactional phase switches to the save transactional phase.

In RAP, cl_abap_tx=>modify( ) corresponds to the RAP interaction and early save phase, while cl_abap_tx=>save( ) corresponds to the RAP late save. Usually, these methods are not needed in RAP behavior implementations. Even more so with cl_abap_tx=>save()  If changes have been made to a RAP business object, the RAP save sequence is executed when this method is called, but without a final commit at the end.

If transactional consistency is violated in an SAP LUW in RAP, for example, an automatic checking mechanism generates either runtime errors or logs. However, this automatic check is only performed in specific cases as shown below.

The controlled SAP LUW determines the following:

  • Transactional phases (modify or save) are set, and in which ABAP code is executed. Starting the phases is done either implicitly (as in RAP) or explicitly (using static methods of the CL_ABAP_TX class).
  • In the transactional phases, transactional contracts are implicitly activated and checked for violations. Certain statements or operations are invalid in these phases. The controlled SAP LUW also checks APIs that are called in your code. These APIs are classified either implicitly with a transactional contract (as is the case for RAP handler and saver methods) or explicitly using IF_ABAP_TX class.
  • Violations of the transactional contracts are either logged for analysis or result in runtime errors - depending on the criteria further down.

The following figure illustrates the controlled SAP LUW.

Here the RAP phases are run through, which can be controlled via the CL_ABAP_TX class. This means we have an interaction phase and the storage sequence, which we can map in our process. In this case, the class is implemented with the interface IF_BGMC_OP_SINGLE, but the EXECUTE method is also available here.

Process

Again, we accept the data in the process and save it for execution. During processing, we can optionally switch to the interaction phase (MODIFY) and accept the data. Since we would actually be working with RAP here, we would send our EML statement. Finally, we switch to the storage sequence and can also send statements such as INSERT or UPDATE to the database.

CLASS zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_process_contr DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_bgmc_op_single.

    METHODS constructor
      IMPORTING it_data TYPE zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data=>tt_data.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    DATA mt_data TYPE zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data=>tt_data.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_process_contr IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD constructor.
    mt_data = it_data.
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD if_bgmc_op_single~execute.
    DATA(lo_table) = NEW zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data( ).

    " Optional
    cl_abap_tx=>modify( ).

    LOOP AT mt_data INTO DATA(ls_data).
      lo_table->add( ls_data ).
    ENDLOOP.

    cl_abap_tx=>save( ).

    lo_table->save( abap_false ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Execution

The execution is very similar to the first variant, the only difference is the SET_OPERATION method that we call to execute our operation. Here too, the process is only triggered after the COMMIT WORK.

DATA lo_operation TYPE REF TO if_bgmc_op_single.

DATA(lt_data) = VALUE zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data=>tt_data(
    ( description = 'Control 1' inumber = 12 amount = '12.54' currency = 'EUR' )
    ( description = 'Control 2' inumber = 95 amount = '0.21' currency = 'USD' )
    ( description = 'Control 3' inumber = 547 amount = '145.50' currency = 'EUR' ) ).

lo_operation = NEW zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_process_contr( lt_data ).

DATA(lo_process) = cl_bgmc_process_factory=>get_default( )->create( ).
lo_process->set_name( 'Controlled Process' )->set_operation( lo_operation ).

lo_process->save_for_execution( ).

Using bgPF [Uncontrolled Variant] 

The uncontrolled variant works without any additional restrictions and we can do whatever we need for our work. To do this, we implement the interface IF_BGMC_OP_SINGLE_TX_UNCONTR in the class, which provides the EXECUTE method. This is later executed during processing.

Process

The class with the interface IF_BGMC_OP_SINGLE_TX_UNCONTR will later be our process that runs in the background. We should therefore make all the data required from our currently running process available to the object.

CLASS zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_process_uncon DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_bgmc_op_single_tx_uncontr.

    METHODS constructor
      IMPORTING it_data TYPE zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data=>tt_data.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    DATA mt_data TYPE zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data=>tt_data.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_process_uncon IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD constructor.
    mt_data = it_data.
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD if_bgmc_op_single_tx_uncontr~execute.
    DATA(lo_table) = NEW zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data( ).

    LOOP AT mt_data INTO DATA(ls_data).
      lo_table->add( ls_data ).
    ENDLOOP.

    lo_table->save( abap_true ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

In this example, the processing consists of taking the transferred data records and persisting them to the database using the SAVE method with COMMIT WORK.

Execution

If we now want to execute our process, we can do this as follows:

  • Creating the operation (our process object)
  • Creating a process using the factory
  • Setting the process name
  • Passing the operation using the SET_OPERATION_TX_UNCONTROLLED method
  • Saving for execution
  • COMMIT for Execution of the process
DATA lo_operation TYPE REF TO if_bgmc_op_single_tx_uncontr.

DATA(lt_data) = VALUE zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_data=>tt_data(
    ( description = 'Test 1' inumber = 12 amount = '12.54' currency = 'EUR' )
    ( description = 'Test 2' inumber = 95 amount = '0.21' currency = 'USD' )
    ( description = 'Test 3' inumber = 547 amount = '145.50' currency = 'EUR' ) ).

lo_operation = NEW zcl_bs_demo_bgpf_process_uncon( lt_data ).

DATA(lo_process) = cl_bgmc_process_factory=>get_default( )->create( ).
lo_process->set_name( 'Uncontrolled Process' )->set_operation_tx_uncontrolled( lo_operation ).
lo_process->save_for_execution( ).

COMMIT WORK.

Execution only begins when COMMIT WORK is set. If a ROLLBACK is performed due to an error, our process does not start either. This is to ensure that the process is only executed if it is successful.

Conclusion

With bgPF and the new way of background processing, you have a simple alternative in ABAP Cloud to outsource processes. You don't even need a function module and can remain completely in the OO context.

entry.title: Monitoring JMX metrics for SAP BTP CloudFoundry applications with SAP Cloud Logging
entry.content:
When we design for observability in our SAP BTP applications, we typically focus on the three pillars: logs, traces, and metrics. The tight integration between the Cloud Foundry runtime environment and SAP Cloud Logging provides application, access, and runtime logs and basic container metrics such as cpu, memory, and filesystem utilization. Distributed tracing can be added with the OpenTelemetry Java Agent which is included in the SAP Java buildpack. Still, a critical piece of the puzzle is often missing for Java applications: deep, internal JVM performance metrics exposed via Java Management Extensions (JMX).

The core problem has always been the same: how do you get these metrics out of a sandboxed Cloud Foundry container and into a central observability platform?

This article provides a complete, step-by-step guide to solving this problem using the OpenTelemetry (OTel) Java Agent's powerful JMX Metric Instrumentation. You will learn how to precisely configure the agent to scrape any MBean, send the data to SAP Cloud Logging, and visualize it directly.

Ultimately, this unlocks the ability to create precise alerts, build custom performance dashboards, and correlate internal JVM behavior with your application's logs and traces for a truly unified view of application health.

In this guide, you will learn how to:

  1. Define Your JMX Metrics: Create a simple YAML configuration file to target specific MBeans, using the java.nio Buffer Pool as a practical example.
  2. Configure the OTel Java Agent: Instruct the agent to scrape these metrics by adding a single system property to your application's deployment manifest.
  3. Verify and Analyze in SAP Cloud Logging: Find your new metrics in the OpenSearch Dashboards, learn the correct syntax for filtering by attributes, and troubleshoot common setup issues like refreshing the index pattern.
  4. Unlock Advanced Observability: Use your new metrics as a foundation for building custom dashboards, defining alerts, and correlating performance data across all your application signals.

By the end, you'll have a powerful, repeatable pattern for gaining deep visibility into any of your Java applications running on the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment.

Prerequisites

To follow this guide, you'll need a working setup that includes:

  • An application deployed to the SAP BTP CloudFoundry runtime environment.
  • A service instance of SAP Cloud Logging with OpenTelemetry support enabled.
  • A service binding of your application to that Cloud Logging service instance.
  • The OpenTelemetry Java Agent configured for your application.

You can follow the documentation of SAP Cloud Logging to create this setup. If you are using SAP Cloud ALM, please refer to the OpenTelemetry@SAP Auto-Instrumentation for Java documentation instead.

After following either guide, your application's JAVA_OPTS environment variable should be configured with the following options. These may be set directly in your manifest.yml or within the credentials of a user-provided service (as is common with the SAP Cloud ALM setup).

'[
  from_environment: false, 
  java_opts: ''
    -javaagent:META-INF/.sap_java_buildpack/otel_agent/opentelemetry-javaagent.jar
    -Dotel.javaagent.extensions=META-INF/.sap_java_buildpack/otel_agent_extension/otel-agent-ext-java.jar
    -Dotel.logs.exporter=cloud-logging
    -Dotel.metrics.exporter=cloud-logging
    -Dotel.traces.exporter=cloud-logging
    -Dotel.resource.attributes=account=<your-calm-account>,calmTenantId=<your-calm-tenant-id>,otel.poll.service.type=SAP_CP_CF
    -Dotel.propagators=sapuniversal
    -Dcom.sap.otel.agentext.defaultLogLevel=INFO
  ''
]'

For the purposes of this article, the most critical line is -Dotel.metrics.exporter=cloud-logging, which ensures that metrics are sent to SAP Cloud Logging. The exporters for traces and logs are optional for this specific task but are highly recommended for a complete observability setup.

Adding the JMX instrumentation

To enable JMX metric scraping, we need to make two changes to our OpenTelemetry Java Agent configuration:

  1. Create a YAML configuration file that defines which MBeans to scrape.
  2. Add a system property to our application's JAVA_OPTS that points the agent to this file.

Let's walk through this with a practical example.

1. Create and Package the Configuration File

First, we'll create the YAML configuration file. If you're using a standard Maven or Gradle project, the easiest place for this file is in the src/main/resources directory. Let's name it jmx-metrics.yaml.

When you build your application, this file will be packaged inside the final JAR.

2. Configure the Java Agent

Next, we must tell the agent where to find our new file. We do this by adding the -Dotel.jmx.config system property to the JAVA_OPTS in our manifest.yml.

For a standard Spring Boot executable JAR, the file from src/main/resources will be located at BOOT-INF/classes/ inside the JAR. Therefore, the property should be:

-Dotel.jmx.config=BOOT-INF/classes/jmx-metrics.yaml

3. Defining the JMX Rules

Now for the most important part: what do we put in jmx-metrics.yaml?

Let's say we want to monitor the java.nio Buffer Pool. We can use a tool like VisualVM with the MBeans plugin to explore available MBeans and find their ObjectName.

The screenshot shows us the MBean domain (java.nio), a key-value pair type=BufferPool, and another key name with values like direct and mapped. To capture metrics for all buffer pools, we can use a wildcard in the ObjectName: java.nio:type=BufferPool,name=*.

We will map the attributes Count, MemoryUsed, and TotalCapacity to OpenTelemetry metrics. The full configuration looks like this:

File: src/main/resources/jmx-metrics.yaml

---
rules:
- bean: java.nio:type=BufferPool,name=*
  mapping:
    Count:
      metric: jvm.buffer.pool.count
      type: updowncounter
      unit: "{buffers}"
      desc: "The number of buffers in the pool."
      metricAttribute:
        pool.name: param(name)
    MemoryUsed:
      metric: jvm.buffer.pool.memory.used
      type: updowncounter
      unit: By
      desc: "An estimate of the memory that the Java virtual machine is using for this buffer pool."
      metricAttribute:
        pool.name: param(name)
    TotalCapacity:
      metric: jvm.buffer.pool.capacity
      type: updowncounter
      unit: By
      desc: "An estimate of the total capacity of the buffers in this pool."
      metricAttribute:
        pool.name: param(name)

A few key things to note in this configuration:

  • type: updowncounter: We use this because these values can both increase and decrease over time. Using a counter clearly indicates that values should be summed when aggregating over different application instances.
  • unit: "{buffers}" and unit: By: These are standard UCUM (Unified Code for Units of Measure) strings that specify the unit is a count of buffers or a size in Bytes.
  • jvm.buffer.pool.name: param(name): This is a powerful feature. It extracts the value from the wildcard part of our MBean (name=*), which will be "direct" or "mapped", and adds it as an attribute named jvm.buffer.pool.name to our metric. This allows you to filter and group your metrics by pool type in SAP Cloud Logging.

With this configuration file added and the system property set, the OpenTelemetry Java Agent will automatically begin scraping these JMX metrics and sending them to your SAP Cloud Logging instance.

Analysing the Metrics in SAP Cloud Logging

With our configuration deployed, we can now navigate to the OpenSearch Dashboards for your SAP Cloud Logging instance.

A great place to start is the pre-built [OTel] Metrics Explorer dashboard. To find our custom metrics, use  first table or the filter bar at the top to set instrumentationScope.name to io.opentelemetry.jmx. You should immediately see the metrics we configured (jvm.buffer.pool.count, etc.) appear in the "Available Metrics" list.

This initial view confirms the metrics are arriving. While this panel doesn't show the metric attributes (like jvm.buffer.pool.name), you can use the dashboard's filtering capabilities to narrow your view.

To do this, you need to use the specific field name that OpenSearch creates for the attribute. OpenSearch replaces dots (.) in attribute names with at-signs (@), so the attribute jvm.buffer.pool.name from our YAML becomes metric.attributes.jvm@buffer@pool@name. You can then add a filter for this field, for example: metric.attributes.jvm@buffer@pool@name: "direct" to isolate metrics for the direct buffer pool.

Pro Tip: Attribute Not Found? Refresh the Index Pattern If you're setting this up for the first time and don't see your new metric.attributes.jvm@buffer@pool@name field available for filtering, you may need to manually refresh the OpenSearch index pattern.

Go to Stack Management > Index Patterns, find the pattern for metrics-otel-v1-*, and click the "Refresh field list" button in the top right.

Scrolling further down the dashboard, you will find a timeline view that plots the metric values over time. This is perfect for spotting trends or changes in your application's behavior.

Conclusion and Next Steps

We have successfully configured the OpenTelemetry Java Agent to scrape custom JMX metrics and send them to SAP Cloud Logging. Seeing the data in the dashboard is just the beginning.

Using these new insights, you can now build more advanced observability solutions, such as:

  • Custom Visualizations & Dashboards: Create dedicated panels to monitor buffer pool usage or any other JMX metric critical to your application.
  • Alerting: Define threshold-based alerts to be notified automatically if, for example, jvm.buffer.pool.memory.used exceeds a certain limit.
  • Anomaly Detection: Leverage OpenSearch's machine learning features to detect unusual patterns in your metrics that could indicate a problem.

The most powerful aspect of this approach is correlation. The SAP BTP extension for the OpenTelemetry agent automatically adds shared resource attributes to all signals—logs, metrics, and traces. These attributes match the ones on the standard Cloud Foundry container metrics (found under instrumentationScope.name: cloud-logging/cloudfoundry-runtime).

This shared context is the key to unified observability, allowing you to seamlessly pivot from a spike in a JMX metric to the corresponding logs and traces from the exact same application instance, dramatically speeding up root cause analysis.

entry.title: Re: RFQ
entry.content:
Thank you for your details, I need one more information,

In the SAP Public Cloud, a Supplier Quotation cannot be submitted unless a price is entered for all items in the RFQ. For example, consider an RFQ containing three materials:

Supplier 1 provides prices for only the first two items.

Supplier 2 provides prices for all three items.

In this case, Supplier 1 offers the best price for the first two items, while Supplier 2’s price is to be considered for the third item. The requirement is to enable the system to award individual line items from different supplier quotations — i.e., to award the first two items to Supplier 1 and the third item to Supplier 2 — even if a supplier has not quoted for all items in the RFQ. Currently, since the system does not allow submission of a quotation without prices for all RFQ items, this functionality cannot be achieved directly. We need a solution or configuration that allows partial quotation submission or item-level award processing in Supplier Quotations.

entry.title: Re: SAP S4HANA public cloud - clearing of bank subaccounts
entry.content:
Hello @panagiotism 

Here are some more information.

The following references will provide you with more details.

Overview on Automatic Bank Statement Processing, Automatic Payments, Automatic Clearing

Schedule General Ledger Jobs, Clear Open Items - Automatic Clearing

To summarise, public cloud edition enables automatic clearing through the Schedule General Ledger Jobs app strictly according to matching criteria defined in the Automatic Clearing Rules (SSCUI 102639).

Even though your open items belong to the same G/L account, the system will only clear them automatically if the key fields between the debit and credit line items match well.

When you used the Manage Automatic Payments app, the system credited the bank subaccount with certain attributes (e.g., reference, assignment, document type text, clearing date). When you imported the bank statement, it created a debit on the same account but with potentially different reference values, which prevents matching automatic clearing.

Finally, the assignment or document type did not match, hence why the automatic clearing job did not connect the two open times. Adjust your automatic Clearing Rules and ensure both posting populate the same Assignment field. After you aligned them, rerun the job and your items will clear automatically.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Shape the Future of AI-Assisted US Sales and Use Tax Support With Us!
entry.content:
We know as you do that maintaining your US sales and use tax information is an exacting and often time-consuming task—that’s why we’re constantly at work to make that part of your day easier.

With that in mind, we’re inviting you to join our customer engagement initiative on the future of AI-assisted sales and use tax calculation and maintenance. We have some ideas, but we need your insights, expertise, and feedback to make sure that these ideas translate into AI-driven solutions that help you.

Here’s what we’re offering:

A sneak peek into our upcoming AI use cases tailored to simplify and enhance your sales and use tax operations;

A chance to be the first to demo these solutions and provide feedback that will directly influence their refinement; and

The opportunity to network with peers and exchange insights about the future of AI in and the overall sales and use tax landscape.

Our AI tools presently help you:

  1. Maintain your tax jurisdictions in a natural, intuitive way.
  2. Speed up onboarding for anyone doing business in the US
  3. Automatically detect and propose missing compliance configurations, simplifying the entire process.

Interested? Great! Let's connect! You can either contact me here on LinkedIn or, even better, directly register to participate in the initiative.

And of course, if you know someone else in your network who might be interested, feel free to pass along this invitation. Tax accountants, tax configuration experts, consultants—anyone who has an interest in or works with sales and use tax. Let’s build the future of AI-assisted tax solutions together!

Thanks!
Anthony Santoro and Ling Zeng

entry.title: Re: COR1 ENHANCEMENT FOR BATCH
entry.content:
Hello @Mahil 

My understanding is that you want to build a custom batch numbering logic depending on the current date. If so, you can use EXIT_SAPLV01Z_002 user-exit to implement such a logic.

The enhancement is documented in SPRO: Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Batch Number Assignment -> Configure Customer Exits for Intern. Batch Number Assignment

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski
